I started housekeeping in 1915 when I was married. Some of this information is years before after my family came to this country.

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Hattie R. Kennedy
Address: Estevan, Sask. Bx 129
Birthplace: M. Galt, Ont.

1. INDUSTRY USES

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1915
Where did you set up housekeeping? Estevan
Where had you been living before that? Estevan
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6 (in 1915)
How far was it to your nearest store? 6 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, sugar, flour, yeast cakes, dried apples, beans, some cheese.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Fine Rice
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
How much did you use graham flour? 200 lbs
Whole wheat flour? 200 lbs
Was flour milled locally? No, how far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.80
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, whole wheat, Farina
Other? Oat meal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? Grain grinder
Kennedy, Mrs. Hattie R.
Box 129, Estill, KY

Where did you get your fuel? Some times we hauled from Regina.

We used wood & coal in our stove, oil in heater since 1943.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Today's cooking seems easier; we have better cooking utensils and better methods of preparing foods.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Clothing was much cheaper. In my diary, I wrote for school wear for my brothers was $0.40 a pair. Muleshoe $1.00-$1.25 a pair, print for dresses $0.75 a yd. Wood was hauled 30 miles in 1905—men left at 3 A.M. got home in 2nd day later.
Indigo working seems lovely.
